Description: Small tear-drop shaped pottery oil-lamp. Mould-made with an elongated round reservoir and partly integral piereced nozzle. Slight raised base. Circular filling hole pierced through the body of the oil-lamp, decorated with a raised ridge. Burnt nozzle. Organic orange-brown (Nile silt?) fabric with gold mica and a sandy texture.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels from Naukratis (Bristol Museum H844; Ashmolean GR.213.1899; GR.214.1899; Bolton Museum 1886.31.8; Nottingham NCM 1888-45; Boston MFA RES.86.131), including a mould (Nottingham, Castle Museum NCM 1888-56). Egyptian parallel from Buto, in the British Museum, has been dated to the 1st century BC (Bailey 1988, Q2093).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.045) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4851 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
